factoid: The assembled guests were present just before a big dinner.
The assembled guests were expecting the summons to zakúska.
The assembled guests avoided engaging in any long conversation.
The assembled guests thought it necessary to move about and talk.
The assembled guests thought it necessary to show that they were not impatient for their food.
The host looked toward the door.
The hostess looked toward the door.
The host occasionally glanced at the hostess.
The hostess occasionally glanced at the host.
The visitors tried to guess from the glances who or what they were waiting for.
The visitors tried to guess if someone important had not yet arrived.
The visitors tried to guess if a dish was not yet ready.
Hors d’oeuvres were served before the main dinner.
Pierre arrived at dinnertime.
Pierre was sitting awkwardly in the middle of the drawing room.
Pierre occupied the first chair he had come across.
Pierre blocked the way for everyone.
The countess tried to make Pierre talk.
Pierre looked around through his spectacles as if searching for somebody.
Pierre answered all the countess's questions in monosyllables.
Pierre was in the way.
Pierre was the only one who did not notice the fact.
Most of the guests knew of the affair with a bear.
Most of the guests looked with curiosity at Pierre.
The guests wondered how Pierre could have played a prank on a policeman.
The countess asked Pierre if he had only recently arrived.
Pierre replied to the countess that yes, madame.
The countess asked Pierre if he had not yet seen her husband.
Pierre replied that he had not seen her husband.
Pierre smiled inappropriately.
The countess asked Pierre if he had been in Paris recently.
Pierre replied that it was very interesting.
The countess exchanged glances with Anna Mikháylovna.
Anna Mikháylovna understood that she was being asked to entertain Pierre.
Anna Mikháylovna sat down beside Pierre.
Anna Mikháylovna began to speak about Pierre's father.
Pierre answered Anna Mikháylovna only in monosyllables.
The other guests were conversing with one another.
The phrase The Razumóvskis... It was charming... You are very kind... Countess Apráksina... was heard on all sides.
The countess rose.
The countess went into the ballroom.
The voice of Márya Dmítrievna was heard in the ballroom.
Márya Dmítrievna answered herself in a rough voice.
Márya Dmítrievna entered the room.
All unmarried ladies rose.
All married ladies except the very oldest rose.
Márya Dmítrievna paused at the door.
Márya Dmítrievna was tall and stout.
Márya Dmítrievna held her fifty-year-old head with gray curls high.
Márya Dmítrievna surveyed the guests.
Márya Dmítrievna arranged her wide sleeves as if rolling them up.
Márya Dmítrievna always spoke in Russian.
Márya Dmítrievna wished health and happiness to the person whose name day was being kept.
Márya Dmítrievna wished health and happiness to that person's children.
Márya Dmítrievna said "Well, you old sinner".
Márya Dmítrievna turned to the count who was kissing her hand.
Márya Dmítrievna said the count was feeling dull in Moscow.
Márya Dmítrievna said the count had nowhere to hunt with his dogs.
Márya Dmítrievna asked what is to be done, old man.
Márya Dmítrievna said just see how the nestlings are growing up.
Márya Dmítrievna pointed to the girls.
Márya Dmítrievna said the girls must look for husbands whether they like it or not.
Márya Dmítrievna asked how her Cossack was.
Márya Dmítrievna called Natásha a Cossack.
Márya Dmítrievna stroked Natásha's arm.
Natásha came up fearless and gay to kiss Márya Dmítrievna's hand.
Márya Dmítrievna said she knows Natásha is a scamp of a girl.
Márya Dmítrievna said she likes Natásha.
Márya Dmítrievna took a pair of pear-shaped ruby earrings from her huge reticule.
Márya Dmítrievna gave the earrings to Natásha.
Natásha beamed with pleasure at her saint’s-day fete.
Márya Dmítrievna turned away at once.
Márya Dmítrievna addressed herself to Pierre.
Márya Dmítrievna said "Eh, eh, friend! Come here a bit".
Márya Dmítrievna said "Come here, my friend".
Márya Dmítrievna tucked up her sleeves higher.
Pierre approached Márya Dmítrievna.
Pierre looked at Márya Dmítrievna in a childlike way through his spectacles.
Márya Dmítrievna told Pierre that she used to be the only one to tell Pierre's father the truth when he was in favor.
Márya Dmítrievna said in your case it is her evident duty.
Márya Dmítrievna praised Pierre as a fine lad.
Márya Dmítrievna said Pierre's father lies on his deathbed.
Márya Dmítrievna said Pierre's father amuses himself setting a policeman astride a bear.
Márya Dmítrievna said it would be better if Pierre went to the war.
Márya Dmítrievna turned away.
Márya Dmítrievna gave her hand to the count.
The count could hardly keep from laughing.
